trial_identification.studytitle: Jejunal versus oral nutrition support for one month after discharge from hospital following oesphagectomy or total gastrectomy - A randomised controlled trial.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In patients discharged from hospital following oesphagectomy or total gastrectomy, what is the effect of one month of jejunal versus oral nutrition support on body weight? A randomised controlled trial

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon

interventions.interventions: One month of overnight continuous jejunal tube feeding using Nutrison Multifibre Energy via an infinity pump for 10 hours from 8pm - 6am after discharge from hospital following oesophagectomy or total gastrectomy, providing 900 calories per night. Patients will administer their own enteral nutrition. Adherence will be monitored at time of follow up with stock checks.
interventions.comparator: One month of oral nutrition support (made up from 3 Nutrison Fortisip drinks per day, spread throughout the day to fit in wiht individual meal plans) for one month on discharge from hospital following oesophagectomy or total gastrectomy, providing 900 calories per day. Adherence will be monitored at time of follow up with stock checks.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Weight (reported in kilograms) - using calibrated scales (and patient recall over the phone where face-to-face followup is not possible)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At one and three months post-discharge from hospital

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life using the EORTC-QLQ-C30 questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At one and three months post-discharge from hospital

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Complications - as reported by the patient
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, one and three months post-discharge from hospital

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Curative oesophagectomy or total gastrectomy. Have a jejunal or Naso-jejunal feeding tube placed during surgery.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Non-curative surgery Limited English or cognitive ability to prevent consent Patients requiring enteral feeding on discharge from hospital due to complications.

trial_design.concealment: Patients will be given Patient Information Sheet by Doctor/Nurse/Dietitian in pre-operative clinic. Once patient starts oral diet post-surgery, the ward dietitian will discuss the project with the patient to assess interest. If consented, the ward dietitian will ring Suzie Ferrie who will randomise the patient to the jejunal or oral group. Central randomisation using sealed envelopes.
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation will be based on drawing a number out of a hat. Stratfication will be based on type of surgery and nutritional status.
trial_design.statisticalmethods:
Basic comparison statistics.
Sample size: For a one-sided statistical significant (a = 0.05 and 80% power) with a 2kg difference between groups (=/- 5.5 SD) N=47 For a two-sided statistical significant (a = 0.05 and 80% power) with a 2kg difference between groups (=/- 5.5 SD) N=60

recruitment.hospital: Royal North Shore Hospital - St Leonards

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Hospital Rd Concord Repatriation Hospital NSW 2139

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of this study is to assess the impact of providing 900 calories from enteral feeding versus oral supplementation for the first month following discharge, for patients who have undergone oesophageal or total gastrectomy surgery.

ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: Royal Prince Alfred Hospital Missenden Rd Camperdown NSW 2050
